Text: A Prayer of the Afflicted when he is faint and pours out his lament before the LORD.
Context: This introductory text sets the tone for the Psalm, indicating that it is a prayer during a time of personal affliction and despair.

Text: Hear my prayer, O LORD; let my cry for help come to You.
Context: The psalmist is asking attentively for God's listening ear, highlighting a sense of urgency and need for divine intervention.

Text: Do not hide Your face from me in my day of distress. Incline Your ear to me; answer me quickly when I call.
Context: The speaker expresses fear of being ignored or abandoned by God during a time of dire need, pleading for a rapid response.

Text: For my days vanish like smoke, and my bones burn like glowing embers.
Context: Imagery of smoke and burning embers conveys the psalmist’s feelings of rapid decline and intense suffering.

Text: My heart is stricken and withered like grass, so that I forget to eat my bread.
Context: Extreme emotional distress impacts the speaker's physical well-being, causing them to neglect basic needs.

Text: From the sound of my groaning, my bones cling to my skin.
Context: Physical manifestation of the psalmist's sorrow and turmoil, emphasizing the severity of their affliction.

Text: I am like a desert owl, like an owl among the ruins.
Context: Use of simile compares the psalmist to solitary creatures, highlighting feelings of isolation and abandonment.

Text: I lie awake; I have become like a lone bird on a housetop.
Context: Continued imagery of solitude, depicting sleeplessness and detachment from others.

Text: All day long my enemies taunt me; those who ridicule me use my name as a curse.
Context: The speaker is tormented by enemies, exacerbating his sense of desolation and distress.

Text: For I have eaten ashes as my bread and mixed my drink with tears
Context: Expression of deep mourning and sadness, using the metaphor of consuming one’s own grief.

Text: Because of Your indignation and wrath; for You have lifted me up and cast me aside.
Context: The psalmist attributes his suffering to God's anger, feeling both elevated and then rejected by God.

Text: My days are like lengthening shadows, and I wither away like grass.
Context: Metaphor of a shadow growing longer as the day ends, symbolizing the psalmist's life fading away.

Text: But You, O LORD, sit enthroned forever; Your renown endures through all generations.
Context: Shifts focus from the self to God’s eternal reign and lasting fame, indicating a turn toward hope.

Text: You will rise up and have compassion on Zion, for it is time to show favor to her; the appointed time has come.
Context: Expresses confidence in God's promised future actions to restore Zion, showing trust in His timing.

Text: For Your servants favor her stones and take pity on her dust.
Context: Affirms the devotion of God's servants to Zion, even in its desolation, showing reverence for the holy city.

Text: The nations will fear the name of the LORD, and all the kings of the earth will revere Your glory.
Context: Anticipates a time when God's power and majesty will be universally acknowledged and respected.

Text: For the LORD will rebuild Zion; He will appear in His glory.
Context: Foretells divine intervention and the restoration of Zion, asserting God’s commitment to His people and dwelling place.

Text: He will regard the prayer of the destitute and will not despise their prayer.
Context: Assures that God attends to the needy and values their prayers, reinforcing His character as compassionate and responsive.

Text: This will be written for the next generation, that a people not yet created may praise the LORD.
Context: The current experiences are to be recorded as a testament for future generations, ensuring that the acts of God will be known and celebrated.

Text: For He looked down from the heights of His sanctuary; from heaven the LORD viewed the earth,
Context: Describes God's sovereign and observant position over the earth, highlighting His awareness of human affairs.

Text: to hear the groans of the prisoners, to release those condemned to death.
Context: Indicates God's attentiveness to suffering and His power to liberate and vindicate the oppressed.

Text: So that the name of the LORD will be proclaimed in Zion and His praise in Jerusalem
Context: Establishes the reason for deliverance: that God may be glorified and honored where His presence dwells.

Text: when the peoples and kingdoms assemble to worship the LORD.
Context: Predicts a future gathering of diverse groups to jointly worship God, emphasizing unity in devotion to the Divine.

Text: He has broken my strength in midcourse; He has shortened my days.
Context: The psalmist returns to lament, feeling that God has diminished his vitality and lifespan before its natural culmination.

Text: I say, "O my God, do not take me away in the middle of my days, your years go on through all generations."
Context: The speaker appeals to God's eternal nature, requesting not to be cut off prematurely from life.

Text: In the beginning You laid the foundations of the earth, and the heavens are the work of Your hands.
Context: Declares God's role as Creator, acknowledging His eternal strength and authority.

Text: They will perish, but You remain; they will all wear out like a garment. Like clothing You will change them, and they will be discarded.
Context: Contrasts the transient nature of the created order with God’s enduring existence.

Text: But You are the same, and Your years will never end.
Context: Affirms God's unchanging character and infinite lifespan, providing reassurance in the midst of temporal concerns.

Text: The children of Your servants will live in Your presence; their descendants will be established before You.
Context: Encourages the faithful with the promise that their lineage will continue in God's favor and care.
